title: Interview: Howth
content:
Social networking is fast becoming one of the quickest ways to discover new or old music; gone are the days of trawling through dingy record stores, instead you can stream any track in the world within seconds of logging onto the internet. In the case of Howth, this method attributes to how I found out about their self titled record, after being recommend them from NY indie band The Antlers facebook page.

Howth are Blake Luley and Carl Creighton, two close friends who have both been involved in numerous musical projects before, yet there is a real sense that this time the music has the capability to be heard by their largest audiences yet. After only one listen to the record it’s clear this is a rather special album, perfectly capturing the essence that is recording from home. Delightfully composed folk tunes mixed with the earthly atmosphere created by recording in domestic and familiar surroundings make for a gripping yet extremely personal listen. The likes of album opener Cooperstown and Idaho #1 showcase the songwriting ability on display, ranging from the bleakly desperate to the subtly beautiful, cementing this record as one of the finest independently recorded albums of 2011 so far. We were delighted to be able to catch up with Howth to find out a little more about the record, their influences and future aspirations.

Check out Howth’s self-titled record.

Crack in the Road: How did Howth come about?

B: Carl and I met while he was recording his first album at the Seaside Lounge where I was interning at the time. I came in while he was recording vocals for a song called “Light bulb” and I was blown away. I asked Carl to be the first artist on a record label I was starting with a friend and Carl was into it. Trouble was my friend and I had no idea what we were doing, so Carl called bullshit on the label but asked if I still wanted to record his album. That was really nice of him, although I really did have every intention of starting a label. Being 20 isn’t the best time to do that though, and I’m probably the least business savvy person ever. We went on to record his 2nd solo album “11 North” at the Seaside Lounge and in my bedroom. No one really bothered to check it out besides our friends. That bummed me out because we had worked for a year on the album and Carl is just such a talented songwriter. I think that was the year that you had to sound like Animal Collectives “Merriweather Post Pavilion” to have anyone listen to your music. Right after we finished “11 North”, we decided to just record a bunch of Carl’s new songs in the basement of our apartment in Brooklyn, NY. It was way more relaxed and laid back then when we were working on “11 North”. I would record Carl then he’d go to class and I’d add some weird keyboard or drum part. I remember one of the last weeks Carl was in town he added a bunch of really wild keyboard parts using this old Yamaha keyboard. I tried really hard to add enough layers to make everything really interesting, but to never get in the way of how awesome Carl’s voice and songwriting is. Carl moved back home to Minnesota and I sporadically worked on the songs throughout 2010, adding some instruments and mixing every song like 100 times. We were going to put it out under Carl’s name and call it Merry Cemetery. I approached Carl about how I thought that was a dumb album title, and he said lets just call the thing Howth and make that our group name too. I think that was what happened.

C: Well, I guess I can explain the name part. I got laid off from my job in March 2008 (which you can hear about on the first song of our album) and then went to France and Ireland for a week to celebrate. The trip was supposed to be solo, but my exboyfriend jumped on the flight to France because he has family there. It was nice and sort of romantic at the time, but I really just wanted to be alone. We split ways when I went to Ireland and he went back to New York. And Howth was this really awesome place I went to when I was there, with the cliff overlooking Dublin Bay. So for me, the name and the band reflects this idea of breaking away from everybody, from expectations and everything else, to just do what you want without having to account to anybody.

CitR: What would you cite as the main inspirations behind Howth, both musically and otherwise?

B: I think the sound of the Howth album was as much a reaction to the first album we made together as it was us trying to really sound like anyone in particular. That being said, I was listening to the Microphones and Sigur Ros a lot when I was adding a lot of instrumental tracks and mixing the album.

C: Yeah, we really wanted to do something that was a little more consistent musically, since 11 North was all over the place. And more stripped down. And more space for Blake to add his magic.

CitR: There’s a real feeling of honesty and realism to your newest record, are many of the songs written about actual events in your lives, or just taking influence from?

C: Yeah. I added some lies for dramatic effect, like the part about having a baby and my grandma dying. But for the most part it’s based on real life. I wouldn’t know what else to write about really. I used to try and write story folk songs like Bob Dylan, but i just always come off as contrived and stupid.

CitR: Do you have any plans to take Howth to a live audience?

B: We actually played 2 shows in Brooklyn and Manhattan the first week that the album came out. Carl was in town for his job training and the timing seemed good. We only got to practice twice so it was a bit patched together. Our friends liked it though! Sadly, at this point in our lives we aren’t able to play live for the time being with work, school, and the distance between us. We will be playing a few shows at next years CMJ festival in New York, and I guess we’ll see from there. I can’t really properly answer that question at this time.

CitR: This release has already, and quite rightly, garnered quite a bit of interest in your music. Do you see yourselves possibly re-releasing your debut record to a larger audience and with greater financial backing?

B: All the money that we are making from donations for the album and people buying physical copies is going toward a proper mastering and pressing of the album. I think we are going to do vinyl because with everyone downloading music CD’s are starting to become really out of style and hard to sell. I feel like CD’s will be as relevant as the laser disc in a few years. Vinyl was awesome when my parents were growing up, and it still sounds great now. As far as greater financial backing, yes please! If you know the dude who owns Rough Trade let him know we could get into that.

C: Please buy our album.

CitR: Increasingly it’s becoming more and more common for artists to record in bedrooms, basements, living rooms etc, how do you think this has the changed the face of the music industry?

B: I think as someone that has made a lot of music in my various apartments and also interned at a really awesome studio (The Seaside Lounge) I’ve seen a good bit of both sides. I think a lot of bands really benefit from a proper studio recording and getting the highest sound quality possible. On the other hand, I feel like a lot of really cool music has come out in recent years that has been recorded in unconventional places. The biggest advantages to that are that you create the schedule of when you are going to record and there is no pressure to finish quickly ’cause your time is free (unlike a studio). I think this has allowed for artists like The Antlers, Sufjan Stevens, and Bon Iver to really find a unique voice with there music. Recording is always a trial and error process but if you aren’t a real professional sometimes your errors become happy mistakes. On the other hand, I think there is a lot of value in recording in a studio. The money pressure can really push you to just go with your gut rather than making a million mixes of the same song. Overall, I think it’s really awesome how easy and cheap it is to make a record in your bedroom. The whole Howth album was made with an old 2 track cassette deck from my mom, a cheap-o 2 input M-Audio recording device, 2 or 3 microphones, and a bunch of random instruments that we had lying around. Considering I was borrowing the M-Audio devices and a few of the mics it was pretty close to a $0 budget album. That was about the only way we could have done it because we were both unemployed and broke at the time. It would have been great to have some nicer gear, but overall it wouldn’t have been the same product in the end.

CitR: What was the first record you can remember falling in love with?

B: The Space Jam soundtrack and Hanson’s first record when I was in 5th grade. By 8th grade I had slightly less embarrassing taste in music and was obsessed with At the Drive In’s “In Casino Out”.

C: Tori Amos’ Boys for Pele. Loved how indulgent it is and the quiet of the piano. Made me want to play music.

CitR: If you could be joined by any musician (alive or dead) on stage for a duet, who would it be?

B: I would say Sigur Ros. Thats a few musicians, but a singular group. Is that okay? I’d just be curious as to how they create such other worldly sounds.

C: PJ Harvey.

CitR: In keeping with “The Wind Blows Cold”, what was the name of your imaginary friend when you were younger?

C: Hmm. I had a cabbage patch doll named Orson. Does that count? I think my imagination was too lazy for imaginary friends when I was a kid.

CitR: If you could be any animal, what would you be?

B: My spirit animal is the red panda or the firefox, as it is sometimes called. I found that out the first time I took mushrooms. My friend just got back from India and said there are monkeys there that steal your shoes and won’t give them back unless you buy them a soda. I could also see myself being one of those monkeys.

C: Sperm whale.
